title: How would you rank each of the closing songs on the 13 albums by The Beatles? - Quora

response.answer_text: In ascending order: 13) Yellow Submarine In Pepperland. Not even a Beatle song closes out the Yellow Submarine album. They should have simply released the four new tracks as an EP. I was 8 1/2 when the album came out and still felt ripped off. Considering how good the film was, they should have cared more about this project. Feh. 12) Money (great lead vocal by John and those fab backing vocals by Paul and George), but I’ve always felt the backing track lumbers when it should swing (just listen to the original version). And knowing where it sits in their intended discography (as opposed to on The Beatles Second Album), it feels a bit formulaic. 11) Everybody’s Trying To Be My Baby. Bouncy enough track, but it feels like an afterthought. And it’s one of the lesser tracks on Beatles For Sale. 10) Dizzy Miss Lizzy. I actually love this track. But it feels like a tossed off, we-need-one-more-to-fill-the-album kind of thing. Particularly as it is tacked onto Help!, which was their second all-original lp until Miss Lizzy rears her lovely head. 9) Get Back. Obviously a big hit. But it was a big hit a year before it appeared on the Let It Be album. And I don’t like the shortened version. It feels incomplete. Lennon’s tag “…I hope we passed the audition”, does put a sad smile on yer face, though, doesn’t it. 8) I’ll Be Back. Interesting for them in that they didn’t close out A Hard Day’s Night with a raver, and it’s a lovely song, but they should have placed one of the r’n b rockers there and given I’ll Be Back a stronger placement. Perhaps track two, side two? Finishing the album seems to somewhat dull it’s impact. 7) Run For Your Life. A nifty rocker. The lyrics haven’t aged well. George’s fav on Rubber Soul. 6) Goodnight. What a lovely way to close out their magnum opus. One more unexpected stylist turn. In the vinyl era it got lost as many folks chose to skip Revolution 9 and along with that track, Goodnight. The Lennon-penned, Ringo-sung lullaby deserved better. George Martin’s string arrangements is sublime. 5) All You Need Is Love. Magical Mystery Tour was never meant to be a full length album, but Capital hit the nail on the head by filling side two with the brilliant 1967 singles. AYNIS, though released as a single four months earlier, perfectly closes out their Summer of Love era. 4) The End. Not a song so much as a bit and a bit and a bit strung together over two minutes. The middle soloing section rocks mightily and Macca’s parting sentiment is the perfect cherry on the top of their career. 3) Twist And Shout. Has any band ever claimed a cover as their own as the Beatles did with this song? Phenomenal feat. As vibrant and exciting today as was in 1963. That’s 57 years ago. Fifty. Seven. 2) Tomorrow Never Knows. Boundaries broken. Minds blown. The Beatles, along with George Martin and Geoff Emerick reached heights they would only hit again in this fashion once more… 1)A Day In The Life. Perhaps the Beatles greatest accomplishment in the studio. It crossed generations. It obliterated what a pop song could be. It was bigger than anything we’d heard up to that point. Even the snooty music critics of the day could only heap praise. It was important. It was inscrutable. And, like Tomorrow Never Knows on Revolver the year before, it took the preceding tracks on the lp and topped even those. It was (and remains), in a word, magnificent.

I’m going to answer it in this way (and I’ll get scolded for it, I know … I’ll post-then-duck!) You know a great-great-GRRRREAT album when you can rattle of opening-and-ending tracks without thinking … and … immediately-recognize the album from it’s first three notes (first two if you’re really good …) Three Beatles albums, to me, are at that level: (1) Sgt. Peppers … the crowd-murmurs … then first three notes and you have it, right? That iconic beginning … and, at the end, the infinite-cosmic-chord at the end of “A Day In The Life.” (you only get to play the first three notes …)   (2) Revolver … the coughing, then just the one-two-three of the initial count-off and you have it, right? And … the tape-loops at the end of “Tomorrow Never Knows” to once again send us into the psychedelic-cosmos at the end. (don’t cheat now … just the first three notes…   (3) Abbey Road: the ‘shoop’ and two notes of the opening bongo/bass should do it, right ... three at most. And … what more-perfect way to end our love affair than with “The End.” (the song about The Queen is just a throw-away, a ‘hidden track’) (you only get two notes this time … did you get it?)   (4) I’ve tried and tried, but can’t leave this one out …The White Album. We all know how it begins … the taxiing engines of the Boeing 707. And the end … of course it’s Ringo lulaby-ing us into slumberland with “Good Night.” (the 707 …)   The soothing strings … Good-Night everyone …
